articles.headline: Small Businesses (and Their Customers) Feel Sting of Inflation
articles.snippet: The cost of doing business keeps rising for small businesses. Having to pay more for goods and fuel means increasing prices, too.
articles.abstract: The cost of doing business keeps rising for small businesses. Having to pay more for goods and fuel means increasing prices, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: From 7 a.m., when Mark Roesner arrives at Copley Feed and Supply in Ohio and turns on the lights, until a little after 6 p.m., when his wife, Nancy Roesner, turns them off, the Roesners are reminded of the costs of inflation in ways big and small.

articles.headline: Bell Canada Takeover Is Blocked
articles.snippet: A surprise ruling could spell the end for a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout that was already struggling.
articles.abstract: A surprise ruling could spell the end for a $51.8 billion leveraged buyout that was already struggling.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA  An appeals court quashed approval for the $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of Bell Canada on Wednesday after siding with angry bondholders in a ruling.

articles.headline: As Obama Heads to Florida, Many of Its Jews Have Doubts
articles.snippet: Jewish voters are vital to Barack Obama’s hopes, but among many older Jews, he has become a conduit for anxiety about Israel, Iran, anti-Semitism and race.
articles.abstract: Jewish voters are vital to Barack Obama’s hopes, but among many older Jews, he has become a conduit for anxiety about Israel, Iran, anti-Semitism and race.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla.  At the Aberdeen Golf and Country Club on Sunday, the fountains were burbling, the man-made lakes were shining, and Shirley Weitz and Ruth Grossman were debating why Jews in this gated neighborhood of airy retirement homes feel so much trepidation about Senator Barack Obama.

articles.headline: McCain Looks to Fill Ticket, and 3 Hopefuls Step Up
articles.snippet: Charlie Crist and Bobby Jindal, both governors, and Mitt Romney, a onetime rival for the nomination, are all set to meet with John McCain this weekend.
articles.abstract: Charlie Crist and Bobby Jindal, both governors, and Mitt Romney, a onetime rival for the nomination, are all set to meet with John McCain this weekend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain of Arizona is set to meet with at least three potential running mates at a gathering at his ranch this weekend in Arizona, suggesting that he is stepping up his search for a vice-presidential candidate as the Democratic contest heads toward a conclusion, according to Republicans familiar with Mr. McCain’s plans.

articles.headline: Israel Holds Peace Talks With Syria
articles.snippet: The governments confirmed that Israel and Syria have begun indirect peace talks, mediated by Turkey, aimed at reaching a comprehensive accord.
articles.abstract: The governments confirmed that Israel and Syria have begun indirect peace talks, mediated by Turkey, aimed at reaching a comprehensive accord.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Israel and Syria announced on Wednesday that they were engaged in negotiations for a comprehensive peace treaty through Turkish mediators, a sign that Israel is hoping to halt the growing influence of Iran, Syria’s most important ally, which sponsors the anti-Israel groups Hezbollah and Hamas.

articles.headline: Senators Sharply Question Oil Officials
articles.snippet: Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee grilled top oil executives over their pay and warned that Congress was intent on taking action that could include a tax on so-called “windfall” profits.
articles.abstract: Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee grilled top oil executives over their pay and warned that Congress was intent on taking action that could include a tax on so-called “windfall” profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee vented their fury over high gasoline prices at executives of the nation’s five largest oil companies on Wednesday, grilling the oilmen over their multimillion-dollar pay packages and warning them that Congress was intent on taking action that could include a new tax on so-called windfall profits.

articles.headline: Concerns From Fed Reverberate on Wall Street
articles.snippet: The hawkish tone of minutes from the Fed’s last meeting, in which policymakers signaled a willingness to halt their rate-cutting campaign, sent the stock indexes tumbling.
articles.abstract: The hawkish tone of minutes from the Fed’s last meeting, in which policymakers signaled a willingness to halt their rate-cutting campaign, sent the stock indexes tumbling.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s aggressive rate-cutting campaign may be at an end.

articles.headline: American, Cutting Back, Plans $15 Bag Fee
articles.snippet: The nation’s largest carrier said it would eliminate free checked baggage and take up to 85 aircraft out of its fleet.
articles.abstract: The nation’s largest carrier said it would eliminate free checked baggage and take up to 85 aircraft out of its fleet.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s an old saying about the best way to travel: bring half the clothes and twice the money.

articles.headline: At One University, Tobacco Money Is a Secret
articles.snippet: A public university has a contract with a company that bars professors from publishing studies without consent.
articles.abstract: A public university has a contract with a company that bars professors from publishing studies without consent.
articles.lead_paragraph: On campuses nationwide, professors and administrators have passionately debated whether their universities should accept money for research from tobacco companies. But not at Virginia Commonwealth University, a public institution in Richmond, Va.

articles.headline: As Oil Prices Rise, Nations Revive Coal Mining
articles.snippet: Soaring commodity prices have been an unanticipated boon to coal producing regions that had written coal mining off as a relic of the Industrial Revolution.
articles.abstract: Soaring commodity prices have been an unanticipated boon to coal producing regions that had written coal mining off as a relic of the Industrial Revolution.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIBAI, Japan  These rugged green mountains, once home to one of Asia’s most productive coal regions, are littered with abandoned mines and decaying towns  backwaters of an economy of bullet trains and hybrid cars.

articles.headline: China Earthquake Pushes Tibet to Sidelines
articles.snippet: Tibetan opponents of Beijing are struggling to compete with China’s growing diplomatic and economic clout.
articles.abstract: Tibetan opponents of Beijing are struggling to compete with China’s growing diplomatic and economic clout.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Dalai Lama toured European capitals this week, the British prime minister closed the door to 10 Downing Street and agreed to meet him only as part of an “interfaith dialogue.” In Germany, most government officials declined to talk with him at all.

articles.headline: 20 Seconds, and a Movie Has Arrived
articles.snippet: This week, Roku and Netflix unveiled a little $100 box that delivers movies directly to your TV — for free — with a regular Netflix membership.
articles.abstract: This week, Roku and Netflix unveiled a little $100 box that delivers movies directly to your TV — for free — with a regular Netflix membership.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, the movie industry raked in more than $40 billion.
